words.def: Double 1
words.name: Annie's Attic

words.def: The number 1.[1][2]
words.name: Annie's room (or Annie's house)

words.def: Another term for darts.
words.name: Arraz

words.def: Another term for darts.
words.name: Arrows

words.def: Refers to a player who throws very quick smooth darts, like an archer's arrow (also known as a 'Derek'). Contrast "Floater".
words.name: Archer

words.def: Darts played with a talking electronic board, popular with visually impaired players. May also be played by blindfolded sighted players.
words.name: Audio Darts

words.def: Average score achieved every three darts thrown. See also PPD.
words.name: Average

words.def: A score of 95, usually by scoring five 19s.
words.name: Baby ton

words.def: A score of 45, named after the prize offered at a fairground.[1]
words.name: Bag of nuts

words.def: A dart term used when a player scores 26 points by hitting a 20, a 5 and a 1. Over the years the term has been used more liberally to describe any combination of darts totalling a score of 26. Commonly coined, "Bag" for short.
words.name: Bagadix

words.def: The part of a dart you grip, right behind the point.
words.name: Barrel

words.def: The double-3.
words.name: Basement

words.def: When someone loses without scoring a point, they are said to have been "brushed" or given the basil brush.
words.name: Basil Brush

words.def: A darter with random and sporadic throwing ability.
words.name: Baz

words.def: A section of a number, usually referring to a double or triple.
words.name: Bed

words.def: Cockney rhyming slang for "two fives".[3]
words.name: Beehives

words.def: A score of 170 to end a leg (triple-20, triple-20, inner bull) (See also: Maximum check-out)
words.name: Big Fish

words.def: A score of 116. Treble 20, single 20, and a loose dart landing in treble 12. Perfected in a local public house in the quaint village of Maryhill in Glasgow.
words.name: Bobby

words.def: When a dart bounces back off the board, usually after hitting a wire.
words.name: Bounce out

words.def: A score of 26, made up of a single-5, single-20, single-1 in a game of x01. This is a common score in darts because players aiming for the 20 sector (which contains the highest scoring area on the board) will often accidentally hit the 1 and the 5 sectors, which are located on either side of the 20. The term comes from the typical price of a bed-and-breakfast in times gone by: 2 shillings and sixpence, or "two and six". (See also chips)
words.name: Breakfast (or bed 'n' breakfast)

words.def: Landing all three darts in the 1. This is also known as "The Eric Bristow", who once scored three 1s in a televised tournament.
words.name: Bucket (or bag) of nails

words.def: A throw when darts land wildly all over the board.
words.name: Buckshot

words.def: The number 33.[1]
words.name: Bull calf

words.def: See diddle for the middle.
words.name: Bull-off

words.def: The centre of the board. (see also: single-bull and double-bull)
words.name: Bullseye (or bull)

words.def: The art of throwing on your knees.
words.name: Bunting

words.def: Hitting more than you needed in an x01 game. The darts do not count and the player begins his next turn on his prior score.
words.name: Bust

words.def: In a game of cricket this refers to high scores based on the number of darts scored. For example a triple-20, single-20, single-20 would be called a C-5 because "5 darts" were scored with three darts.
words.name: C

words.def: Darts thrown such that they miss the board entirely and hit a wooden frame which is holding the board to the wall. (See also: masonry darts):
words.name: Carpentry darts

words.def: Hitting triple 20, triple 1 and triple 5 in three darts. (See also breakfast)
words.name: Triple Jan Visser

words.def: Scoring exactly the score that is left, to win the leg. A final double is required to win a leg in an x01 game.
words.name: Checkout

words.def: A player who just "chucks" the darts at the board, doesn't aim or care.
words.name: Chucker

words.def: When a player scores a single digit (less than 10) with three darts, his team-mates would shout out "Circle it!" to the scorekeeper to highlight the terrible throw. A variation on this tradition is to draw a fish around the score, often leading to aquarium-related jokes being aimed at particularly poor or unlucky players. (See also: fish)
words.name: Circle it

words.def: The dartboard itself, usually in the context of round the clock.
words.name: Clock

words.def: Going out with a bull/double bull.
words.name: Conquistador

words.def: The center of the board. This comes from the cork in the end of a keg where it is tapped. The ends of kegs were used for targets in the game's early days.
words.name: Cork

words.def: Aiming for an alternate triple, usually 19, when a previously thrown dart is blocking the triple 20.
words.name: Cover

words.def: Two distinct game variations. The American game is known by many different names, such as "Mickey Mouse", outside North America, where cricket refers to a different game, which is often called "Australian Cricket".[4]
words.name: Cricket

words.def: See right church, wrong pew
words.name: Daddy's bed, daddy's, daddy

words.def: A throw that is 'spread' around the board, named after the cheese spread Dairylea.
words.name: Dairylea darts

words.def: The triple-6, so called due to '666', and the fact that it is often hit in error when going for triple-13 or triple-10.
words.name: Devil

words.def: When the dart lands on the other side of the wire of the area aimed for. Then yelling an expletive.
words.name: Deming

words.def: When it is inevitable that bull will be hit. For the whole day after whoever achieves this must be referred to as 'bull'.
words.name: Destiny bull

words.def: A throw of a single dart to determine who throws first in the game by means of being closer to the bullseye. Also known as a "bull-off", "middle for middle", "corking" and "out for bull".
words.name: Diddle for the middle

words.def: The thin outer ring of the board. In standard x01 games, a double counts for two times the number hit.
words.name: Double

words.def: On dartboards configured with a bullseye consisting of two concentric circles, double-bull refers to the inner circle, which is commonly red and worth 50 points. (See also: bullseye and single-bull)
words.name: Double-bull

words.def: A variant of x01 in which a double is needed to start the game.
words.name: Double in

words.def: The double-20.
words.name: Double top

words.def: Not being able to hit the double needed to win the game.
words.name: Double trouble

words.def: The lower portion of the board, usually in reference to the 19s in a game of x01.
words.name: Downstairs

words.def: Same as straight in; a game that requires no special shot to begin scoring.
words.name: Easy in

words.def: The art of adjusting ones stance or position along the oche in an attempt to circumnavigate a troublesome 'blocking' dart. Also referred to as The Milk Float.
words.name: Eddie shuffle (The)

words.def: The number 33.[1] Also may refer to flights, since early flights were made from feathers.
words.name: Feathers

words.def: A score of nine or less, usually denoted by drawing a whale around the score on the scoreboard. (See also circle it and whale).
words.name: Fish

words.def: Hitting 20, 1, and 5 for 26. (see also breakfast)
words.name: Fish and chips (or feed)

words.def: A series of castaway darts thrown with no other purpose than to irritate opponents.
words.name: Fogle

words.def: The "wings" at the end of a dart that help it fly straight and land point first. Also known as feathers.
words.name: Flights

words.def: Called by the referee to advise all players that the match has now started.
words.name: Game on

words.def: Called by the referee to signify that the match winning double has been hit.
words.name: Game shot

words.def: Hitting the double next to the one being aimed for.
words.name: Goldilocks

words.def: A loss without scoring, see shut out.
words.name: Granny

words.def: The third dart thrown, when it manages to avoid scoring a FISH or a WHALE which was looking likely after the first two darts had been thrown. So called because the player is said to have "saved the fish" or "saved the whale".
words.name: Greenpeace dart

words.def: A score of three bullseyes. Also known as the Alan Evans shot, who scored three bulleyes during a match on numerous occasions.
words.name: Hat-trick

words.def: A cry from the crowd in recognition of the fact that one of the players is struggling to successfully complete a leg.
words.name: He doesn't want it

words.def: A score greater than 150.
words.name: High ton

words.def: Refers to a player who throws well despite intoxication.
words.name: Hot toddy

words.def: The actual playable area of a dart board (inside the doubles ring). Missing this area entirely is sometimes referred to as "off the island".
words.name: Island

words.def: In Japanese it means "Strawberry Disease" but taken apart it, the word strawberry: "ichigo" can mean 1 (ichi) and 5(go). Japanese players use this term for when they aim at 20 but hit a 5 and a 1 along with the intended 20. It is equivalent to the English term breakfast.
words.name: Ichigo-byo

words.def: Two single 1s and a triple 1; ie: it would be worth 100 if it were five 20s instead of five 1s.
words.name: Irish Ton

words.def: Going out with a double/double
words.name: Iron Man

words.def: If a player checks out when their opponent's score is 200 or greater they are said to have jugged their opponent. This is because in social darts the punishment for the player not to check out is to drink a jug of beer without stopping following the match.
words.name: Jugging

words.def: A game variant where a number of players "own" a number on the dartboard and compete to build up "lives" (by hitting that number) until a threshold is reached (usually 4 or 6) before attempting to "kill" other players by removing the lives they have built up (by hitting those other players' numbers) until a single player is left.[4]
words.name: Killer

words.def: One game of a match. Most professional matches are made up of a number of sets, each of which is split into legs.
words.name: Leg

words.def: Signifies that a player has completed (won) the "leg".
words.name: Leg shot

words.def: Usually refers to triple 20, as this portion of the board is commonly red in color and resembles an upper lip, but may refer to any red double or triple.
words.name: Lipstick

words.def: The double-1. At least two explanations for the term have been proffered; because it can drive you crazy trying to hit one in a game of x01, or because it is impossible to "get out" of the mad house - once a player has a score of 2 the only way to finish the game is by hitting a double-1.[2]
words.name: Mad house

words.def: A dart that has landed off target but very close, the dart is used as guide.
words.name: Marker

words.def: Cockney rhyming slang for "darts".
words.name: Martial Arts

words.def: Darts thrown such that they miss the board entirely and hit the wall instead (i.e. even worse than carpentry darts).
words.name: Masonry darts

words.def: A score of 180
words.name: Maximum

words.def: A score of 170 to end a game (triple-20, triple-20, inner bull)
words.name: Maximum check-out

words.def: An unorthodox finish to a game such as finishing 101 with (3,T20,D19), a cheeky (3,8,D20), perhaps even a 113 outshot with (17,T20,D18) or other less popular routes. Also referred to as Maverick play. This kind of play was popularised by Belgian Eric Clarys, who used bizarre ways of checking out on televised events.
words.name: McQuiggin's gold

words.def: See cricket.
words.name: Mickey Mouse

words.def: See diddle for the middle.
words.name: Middle for middle

words.def: A person who deliberately scores many more points than needed to win the game.
words.name: Monger

words.def: Loser of the previous game goes first in the next game.
words.name: Mugs away

words.def: A score of single-5, single-20, single-1 in a game of x01. Based on Murphy's Law. (See also: breakfast) and Fish and chips (or feed)
words.name: Murphy

words.def: Another word for 1. See also: bucket of nails and ton of nails.
words.name: Nail

words.def: When a player completes a game of 501 in the minimum required nine-darts. This is a very rare event. There is usually a cash prize for professionals throwing a televised nine-darter.
words.name: Nine darter

words.def: When you finish with two singles of the same value.
words.name: Nish

words.def: A traditional cry from opponents or spectators when a player deliberately switches to aiming at a different part of the board in order to avoid an embarrassing score such as a fish or a wanker's fifty.
words.name: No sense of humor

words.def: A score of 37 (usually by hitting a 20, a 5 and a 12). The phrase is believed to have its origins in a Monty Python sketch (King Arthur & Dennis, in "Monty Python & the Holy Grail").
words.name: Not old

words.def: The line from behind which a player throws.
words.name: Oche

words.def: A list of the optimal checkouts for all numbers from 2 to 170. Often written on a small card that comes with, when buying new boards or darts.
words.name: Out chart

words.def: See diddle for the middle.
words.name: Out for bull

words.def: Called by the referee to announce that a player has scored a maximum.
words.name: One-hundred-and-eighty!

words.def: See nine darter.
words.name: Perfect game

words.def: See maximum.
words.name: Perfect score

words.def: See maximum check-out.
words.name: Perfect finish

words.def: When the darts land so close to each other, they knock their flights out.
words.name: Popcorn

words.def: Average "points per dart" thrown. See also average.
words.name: PPD

words.def: Achieved by hitting 20, 5 and 1, while aiming for the treble 20.
words.name: Pub score

words.def: Australian term for hitting the required double to finish an 01 game.
words.name: Peg out

words.def: A dart, (often a T20) that "redeems" two previous poor efforts.
words.name: Redeemer

words.def: Term for hitting a double or triple, but the wrong number. Also known as daddy's bed.
words.name: Right church, wrong pew (or right house, wrong bed)

words.def: Throwing a dart into the shaft of another making it stick, sometimes splitting the flight.
words.name: Robin Hood

words.def: Throwing three triples that close (before being closed by opponent) or point in one turn in cricket.
words.name: Round nine

words.def: Any of a number of game variants where players compete to be the first to hit all the sectors on the board in an agreed order, usually numerical finishing with the 20,[4] although sometimes with the outer bull followed by the bull. In some versions hitting a double entitles the player to skip the next number, with a triple entitling the player to skip two numbers. Also commonly played by single players as a form of practice; also known as around the world.
words.name: Round the clock

words.def: A dart that is aimed for triple 20, but ends up in double 20.
words.name: Scroat

words.def: Aiming for something and hitting something else that either marks or points.
words.name: Scud

words.def: A scoring method used in many tournaments.
words.name: Set

words.def: The placement of player(s) automatically in a tournament where some have to qualify, or automatic placement in later rounds.
words.name: Seeding

words.def: The part of a dart behind the barrel where the flights are mounted.
words.name: Shaft

words.def: Refers to hitting a single, double and triple of the same number. As a game in itself, players throw at each number on the board in turn, scoring points, with the first player to hit a Shanghai being declared the winner. If no player achieves a Shanghai, then the player with the most points wins.[4] In some variations Shanghai is not an automatic win, but is rewarded with bonus points. As a turn, Shanghai, particularly on 20, may also be played in any normal game and may be used as a classic winning "checkout", to end the leg, provided the double is thrown last.
words.name: Shanghai

words.def: A non-registered player who assumes a false identity in order to fill in for an absent player in a league game.
words.name: Sharkey

words.def: All three darts thrown at one time.
words.name: Shotgun blast

words.def: A Bullesye that wins any non-competitive match, as long as before throwing you declared your intention by stating clearly "Shropshire Bull".
words.name: Shropshire Bull

words.def: When you lose a game without ever scoring in it.
words.name: Shut out

words.def: On dartboards configured with a bullseye consisting of two concentric circles, single-bull refers to the outer circle, which is commonly green and worth 25 points. This is also known as the 'outer bull'. The inner circle is commonly red and worth 50 points. There is speculation to whether this is called the bullseye or indeed called the target. See also: bullseye and double-bull.
words.name: Single-bull

words.def: When you lose a game without ever scoring in it.
words.name: Skunked

words.def: Darts that score, but not where you wanted them, also known as a scud.
words.name: Slop

words.def: Another name for a game of darts.
words.name: Smoke Break

words.def: The metal web that divides the dartboard into sections.
words.name: Spider

words.def: throwing two or more darts at the board at the same time. Hitting a scoring number that was not the intended target.
words.name: Splash

words.def: Darts thrown aimlessly.
words.name: Spray and pray

words.def: Another name for a game of darts
words.name: Spud

words.def: The darts themselves.
words.name: Sticks

words.def: A game that requires no special shot to begin scoring (also "straight off").
words.name: Straight in

words.def: A game that requires no special shot to finish a game. i.e. Players on 15 can hit the S15 to win instead of going S7, D4.
words.name: Straight out

words.def: Hitting a double bull when diddling for the middle – comes from the Gulf War, when Iraq was being bombed, as Iraq has lots of oil. (See striking oil).
words.name: Striking Iraq

words.def: Hitting a double bull when diddling for the middle. So called because of the black centre to the bullseye of some modern dart boards.
words.name: Striking oil

words.def: The centre of the board, though some call it the bullseye there is speculation to the real name.
words.name: Target

words.def: A widely used term by television commentators when something unexpected or extraordinary occurs during a game.
words.name: That's darts

words.def: Three darts in the same number, no matter double or triple.
words.name: Three in a bed

words.def: See oche.
words.name: Throw line

words.def: See oche.
words.name: Toe line

words.def: Three darts in the triple 20 which score 180 points; only in x01 games. See maximum.
words.name: Ton 80

words.def: A score of 100 in a game of x01. Scores over 100 would be called a "ton-whatever" for example, a ton-thirty would be a score of 130.
words.name: Ton

words.def: A score of 5 where all three darts fell in the 1 bed with 1 dart in the triple 1.
words.name: Ton of nails

words.def: Double 20. Usually exclaimed after hitting this bed to win a match.
words.name: Top banana

words.def: Double 20.
words.name: Tops

words.def: The thin inner ring of the board, it usually counts for three times the number hit.
words.name: Triple (or treble)

words.def: At the beginning and/or ending of a x01, you must hit the triple ring to start/end the game.
words.name: Triple in, triple out

words.def: 30 points
words.name: Turkey

words.def: The upper half of the board
words.name: Upstairs

words.def: Usually refers to hitting the triple either side of the triple 20 (triple 1 or triple 5) but may refer to any green bed on the board.
words.name: Veg Patch

words.def: Crude term for scoring 50 by hitting single 20, single 18 and single 12 with three darts, so called because often poor players achieve it when aiming for the triple 20.
words.name: Wanker's fifty

words.def: When the losing player starts the next leg - similar to Mugs away.
words.name: Wanker's off

words.def: Standing too close to the board, i.e that is, in front of the oche.
words.name: Wet feet (or paddling)

words.def: A score of nine or less (i.e. averaging 3 or less per dart). Usually denoted by drawing a whale around the score on the scoreboard.
words.name: Whale

words.def: Scoring three triples in cricket without scoring points.
words.name: White horse

words.def: Darts that just miss where you aimed but on the other side of the spider.
words.name: Wire

words.def: When a player closes a single number using all 3 darts in 'cricket.
words.name: Workin' man's darts
